Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multiscale engineering of active stress in biomaterials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Abstract:
Biological systems exhibit remarkable behaviors, including the ability to heal, reproduce, and be self-motile. Conventional synthetic materials do not display such properties because they are composed of inanimate molecules. In contrast, biological systems consist of active, energy transducing molecules which continuously push and pull on each other, producing active stresses. These active stresses make biological systems examples of active matter, and are ultimately are responsible for many of their unusual behaviors. Creating artificial active matter opens up a new route towards constructing materials with lifelike functionalities. However, a significant obstacle to realizing this possibility is an absence of understanding of how active stresses are produced: given specific elemental building blocks, there are not currently tools to either measure or theoretically predict the magnitude, type, or even the sign of the active stresses. The project will elucidate the foundational principles of active stress generation using a synergistic combination of experiments, simulations, and theory. The work will result in the creation of new experimental tools for measuring active stresses, new synthesis procedures for creating active materials, and new multi-scale modeling techniques for studying active matter. An integrated outreach program will bring the excitement of active matter to K-12 education, undergraduates, and graduates by combining interactive demonstrations, advanced interdisciplinary training, and intensive summer courses.

Technical Abstract:
The research focuses on studying assemblages of microtubules and kinesin-14 molecular motors. The work addresses three fundamental challenges in understanding active stresses generated by such active materials. First is the development of tools to measure active stresses at different length scales using optical tweezers, fluid flow measurements, microfluidics, and 3D printing, in combination with theory and simulations. Second, a novel system will be created in which active stress generation will be modulated by directly affixing kinesin-14 to microtubules in predetermined patterns. Theory and simulations will be used to guide which patterns to create, and conversely, measuring the resulting active stress generation in these designed materials will provide a stringent test of theory and simulations. Third, a multi-scale modeling framework will be developed and tested. These will be subsequently related to each other through a combination of analytical calculations and simulations. The resulting models will be made with continual feedback from experiments. Taken together, this work will establish new paradigms to study, understand, and engineer active stresses in active materials.

This DMR grant supports research to understand the assemblages of microtubules and kinesin-14 molecular motors with funding from the Condensed Matter Physics (CMP) and Biomaterials (BMAT) Programs in the Division of Materials Research of the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mathematical models and simulations are developing into important tools through which to study important phenomena in biology. In this grant, we developed mathematical models and specialized software to study the forces and stresses that shape the responses of active biological systems. One important class of examples are materials made from elements of the so-called cytoskeleton. The cytoskeleton is a collection of biological polymers, molecular motors, and other elements found within cell, that act collectively to exert forces and stresses and so move or position internal structures (or, indeed, to move the cell itself).

In our work we developed tools to study the organizational dynamics of cytoskeletal assemblies. This included the development of a software package called aLENS for efficiently simulating the pattern-forming dynamics of large numbers of cytoskeletal elements, and another package -- SkellySim -- that captures how microtubules -- a particularly stiff biopolymer used in cells to exert forces -- interact through the induced motions of the cell's fluidic interior. We also developed so-called "continuum models" that compactly represent the collective interactions of the cytoskeleton in terms of partial differential equations for material density, stresses, and configurations. We have used these models as analytical lenses through which to study instabilities and large-scale dynamics of these biologically active materials.

Some of the specific outcomes have included combined experimental and theoretical studies of biologically active materials that mimic mitotic spindles, showing how spindle-like behavior is found in the limit of having many molecular motors at work; How active forces and stresses guide the positioning of cellular organelles; How large-scale cellular flows -- important for the development of organisms -- can emerge from the interaction of motors, microtubules, and fluid; the development of efficient and accurate continuum models -- using so-called closure techniques based on maximizing entropy or upon machine learning -- that can be applied to study activity-driven turbulence or the interaction of active fluids with structures.  

These studies inform our understanding of very basic, but poorly understood, biological phenomena, guide the rational development of new active materials for engineering and technology, and will help in develop large-scale models of cellular behaviors and so impact human health.
